BasicIO

Class BasicForm

  • java.lang.Object
    • BasicIO.BasicForm

  • public class BasicForm
extends java.lang.Object

    BasicForm provides an easy way of giving Java applications a graphical user interface.

    BasicForm creates a form that may have components added to it: labels, textfields, textareas, checkboxes, sliders, radio buttons, pictures, audio and buttons. These components can be read from and written to, making the BasicForm a source of data input for a program, and a means of the program to display output data.


    Adding Components to a BasicForm
    For each type of component (with the exception of buttons) there is an addXXXXXX method. (eg. addTextField()) that adds a component of that type to the BasicForm. With each of the add methods there is an optional String parameter for the component's name which is used to access the component for reading, writing, getting attributes etc. If a name is not specified then attributes of the component cannot be accessed, but the component may still be accessed for reading and writing as described in Reading and Writing, below. A BasicForm expands to include all the fields added to it.

    Along with the optional name parameter, some components have additional parameters. The list below are the most common ones amongst the components. For specific parameters see the method summaries below.

    label - a string to label the component on the BasicForm. The label auto sizes to the size of the text passed. If a label is not specified when the component is created, it cannot be added later on. Similarly the size of the label remains constant from its creation. If a longer string is passed as new text for the label, the text will be truncated, or if a shorter string is passed, it will be padded the right. For this reason it is a good idea to provide a label of ample size when adding components. To make things line up nicely you should provide Strings of equal length for all of your labels.

    width and height - the width and height of a component in pixels. TextFields and TextAreas do not have width and height parameters. The height of a TextField is static and cannot be set and it's width may be changed by specifying a size. The size specifies how many characters will be able to fit into the textbox. TextAreas have nRows and nCols, the number of rows and columns the TextArea can display.

    x and y - the top left hand corner of the component. If the component has a label, the x and y will be the top left hand corner of the label. In Java the top left hand corner of the window is (0,0) and both x and y increase as you move to the right and down.

    Default Parameters
    If a parameter is omitted, default values are used as follows:
    name - no name, component cannot be accessed in methods by providing a name
    label - no label
    width and height - each component has its own set of defaults for its size
    x and y - the component will be placed directly below the lowest component on the form along the left side of the form with small gaps between it and the component above it and between it and the edge of the window.



    Reading and Writing
    Reads and writes can be performed on most components. There are 2 ways of specifying which component is read/written from/to.

    1. Specifying the component name:
    By specifying the name of a component in the read and write methods, you can read/write from/to any component on the BasicForm at any time.

    2. Not providing a name of the component:
    There is an invisible cursor that cycles through all of the components on the BasicForm. Every time a read or write is performed the cursor moves to the component following the component read/written. When the last component is accessed, the cursor will cycle back to the first component. The order in which the cursor cycles through the components is based on order in which the components are added to the form. If you do not provide the read and write methods with a component name, the read/write is performed on the component indicated by the cursor.
    - If all reads/writes are done without supplying a name, the components are read/written from/to in the order in which they were added to the form.
    - If a name is used to perform a read/write operation, followed by a read/write operation without providing a name, the second read/write will be perfromed from/to component following the one read/written from/to with the name.



    Formats
    Format objects can be provided with read and write methods. A Format object may be used to change the visual look of the output, for instance if you write an int of value 1000 while providing a Format object to make it look like a currency the output may be "$1,000.00". If you were to try use readInt without a format the operation would fail as it would be unable to interpret "$1,000.00" as an int. Providing the same Format object with the readInt method here would allow readInt to return the value 1000.

    A TextField can have a default formats which will automatically be used to format any data read/written from/to it. If a read or write operation is performed on a textfield that has a default format, then the format object passed in the read/write method temporarily overrides the default format.



    The 3 States of a BasicForm
    A BasicForm has 3 states:
    Invisible - the form is not visible on the screen. The program creating the form is running and can interact with the form. This is the initial state of a form and may be achieved at any time via the hide() method.
    Visible - the form is visible on the screen. The program creating the form is running and can interact with the form. The buttons on the form are not visible indicating to the user that s/he cannot interact with the form. This state automatically occurs after the user presses a button when the form is in the User has Control state and may be achieved at any time via the show() method.
    User has Control - the form is visible on the screen and the program creating the form is suspended awaiting user input. The buttons are visible and the user may interact with the form. When the user presses a button, the form goes to the Visible state, allowing the program to interact with the form and/or make the form invisible. This state may be achieved via the accept() method.


    Buttons
    Whenever the form in in User has Control state, one or more buttons are displayed to allow the user to select one or more actions when dismissing the form. A default set of buttons for the form can be specified supplying a set of button names (String) in the BasicForm constructor. If no default button names are provided, the default will be one button named OK. Buttons are shown whenever the accept() method is called. If the accept method has no parameters, the default buttons are displayed. A different set of buttons can be displayed by providing a set of button names (String) as parameters to the accept method. These temporarily override the default buttons.

    The buttons on the form are used by the user to dismiss the form, returning it to the Visible state, and giving control back to the program. The accept() method returns an int whose value is based on the button pressed. If the first button was pressed a 0 will be returned, the 2nd button will return a 1. The nth button will return n-1. The buttons are numbered based on the order they were passed to the BasicForm constructor or accept method.



    Exceptions
    Exceptions can be thrown when 'problems' occur. If an exception occurs and is not caught the program will crash. There are 4 kinds of Exceptions that may occur.
    ComponentNotFoundException - is thrown if a read or write operation cannot find a component with the specified name on the form.
    IllegalOperationException - is thrown if an operation is performed on an incompatible component, e.g. trying to place a picture onto a textfield.
    NameAlreadyExistsException - is thrown if a component is added with a name identical to an existing component on the form.
    NoComponentOnFormException - is thrown if an operation is attempted to be performed on a component which does not exist on the form.


    Sample Code demonstrating writing and reading from a component.

    String field2output;
    BasicForm form = new BasicForm();
    form.addTextField("field1");
    form.addTextField("field2");
    form.writeString("field1", "this is field 1");
    form.accept();
    field2output = form.readString("field2");

    Version:
    1.0 July 08, 2.0 (09/05/04), 3.0 (09/06/30)
    Author:
    Andrew Cheesman, David Hughes, David Hughes

      • BasicForm

        public BasicForm(java.lang.String... buttons)
        Creates a form with the specified deafult buttons. If no Strings are provided there will be one default button labeled OK. Otherwise each String passed will be a default button, with the String being the text on the button.
        Parameters:
        buttons - the Strings which represent the default buttons on the form.

      • BasicForm

        public BasicForm()
        Creates a form with one default button labeled OK. // * // * @param width the minimum width of the form // * @param height the minimum height of the form

    • Method Detail

      • successful

        public boolean successful()
        Returns true if the last operation (eg readxxx, writexxx) was succesful, false otherwise. An operation can be unsuccessul if:
        - the data can not be converted to the required type, isDataError returns true.
        - the data can not be formated, isFormatException returns true.
        - the EOF has been reach on the component when a read operation is performed, isEOF returns true.
        Returns:
        boolean indicating if last operation was successful.

      • isEOF

        public boolean isEOF()
        Returns true if last operation failed due to reading when at EOF.
        Returns:
        a boolean indicating if last operation failed due reading when at EOF.

      • isFormatException

        public boolean isFormatException()
        Returns true if last operation failed due to being unable to format data.
        Returns:
        a boolean indicating if last operation failed due to being unable to format data.

      • isDataError

        public boolean isDataError()
        Returns true if last operation failed due to being unable to convert the data to the specified type.
        Returns:
        a boolean indicating if last operation failed due to being unable to convert the data to the specified type.

        Returns the x co-ordinate of the top left corner of a component on the form
        Parameters:
        name - the name of the component.
        Returns:
        the x co-ordinate of the top left corner of the component.
        Throws:
        ComponentNotFoundException - none of the components on the BasicForm have the specified name.

      • show

        public void show()
        Makes the form visible on the screen, putting the form into the Visible state. The components on the form are not editiable by a user until the accept() method is called.

      • hide

        public void hide()
        Makes the form invisible on the screen, putting the form into the Invisible state. The form still exists when hidden and can be accessed via program control.

      • accept

        public int accept()
        The form is made visible with the default buttons and the program is suspended, putting the form into User has Control state. The user may interact with the form ending the interaction (dismissing the form) by pressing a button. An int value is returned based on which button is pressed. The first button will return a value of 0, the 2nd a value of 1. The nth button will return a value of n-1.
        Returns:
        the int value of the button pressed

      • accept

        public int accept(java.lang.String... buttons)
        The form is made visible with the specified buttons and the program is suspended, putting the form into User has Control state. The user may interact with the form ending the interaction (dismissing the form) by pressing a button. An int value is returned based on which button is pressed. The first button will return a value of 0, the 2nd a value of 1. The nth button will return a value of n-1.
        Parameters:
        buttons - buttons that will be displayed
        Returns:
        the int value of the button pressed

      • setEditable

        public void setEditable(java.lang.String name,
                        boolean editable)
        Sets the edit state of the component. If editable is false, the component on the form can not be modified by the user when the form is in User has Control state. Otherwise the user will be able to modify the value in the component. The default edit state is editable (true).
        Parameters:
        name - the name of the component
        editable - the component is editable
        Throws:
        ComponentNotFoundException - none of the components on the BasicForm have the specified name.

      • isEditable

        public boolean isEditable(java.lang.String name)
        Returns true if the component is set to editable, false otherwise.
        Parameters:
        name - the name of the component
        Returns:
        boolean the component is currently editable
        Throws:
        ComponentNotFoundException - none of the components on the BasicForm have the specified name.

      • addLabel

        public void addLabel(java.lang.String name,
                     java.lang.String label,
                     int x,
                     int y)
              throws NameAlreadyExistsException
        Adds a label with the specified name, text and x,y co-ordinate to the form. If a string for the label is not provided, an empty label of 20 characters will be created. Otherwise the size of the label will be the size of the String "label". Leaving out the other paramters will result in them having their default values. (see default values above) All of the parameters are optional, and possible combinations of them can be seen below.
        Parameters:
        name - the name of the label component.
        label - the text the label displays.
        x - The x co-ordinate of the top left corner of the label.
        y - The y co-ordinate of the top left corner of the label.
        Throws:
        NameAlreadyExistsException - the name has already been used for another component.

      • addTextField

        public void addTextField(java.lang.String name,
                         java.lang.String label,
                         java.text.Format f,
                         int size,
                         int x,
                         int y)
                  throws NameAlreadyExistsException
        Adds a text field with the specified name, label, default format, size and x,y co-ordinate to the form. Leaving the name blank will prevent the text field from being accessed other than by iterating through all components on the form. Leaving out the label will create a text field without a a label. Leaving out the other paramters will result in them having their default values. (see default values above) All of the parameters are optional, and possible combinations of them can be seen below.
        Parameters:
        name - the name of the text field component.
        label - the text to be displayed in the label.
        f - the default format for the text field.
        size - the size of the text field in characters.
        x - the x co-ordinate of the top left corner of the label/text field
        y - the y co-ordinate of the top left corner of the label/text field
        Throws:
        NameAlreadyExistsException - the name has already been used for another component.

      • addTextArea

        public void addTextArea(java.lang.String name,
                        java.lang.String label,
                        int nRow,
                        int nCol,
                        int x,
                        int y)
        Adds a text area, with the specified name, label, number of columns, number of rows and x,y co-ordinate to the form. Leaving the name blank will prevent the text area from being accessed other than through iterating through all components on the form. Leaving out the label, will created an unlabeled text area. Leaving out nRows and nCols will create a text area 12 rows by 50 columns. Leaving out the other paramters will result in them having their default values. (see default values above) All of the parameters are optional, and possible combinations of them can be seen below.
        Parameters:
        name - the name of the text area component.
        label - the text to be displayed in the label.
        nCol - the number of columns the text area will have (in lines)
        nRow - the number of rows the text area will have (in characters)
        x - The x co-ordinate of the top left corner of the label/text area
        y - The y co-ordinate of the top left corner of the label/text area
        Throws:
        NameAlreadyExistsException - the name has already been used for another component.

      • addTextArea

                        java.lang.String label,
                        int nRow,
                        int nCol)
        See Also:
        addTextArea(String name, String label, int nRow, int nCol, int x, int y )

      • addRadioButtons

        public void addRadioButtons(java.lang.String name,
                            java.lang.String label,
                            boolean vertical,
                            int x,
                            int y,
                            java.lang.String... buttons)
                     throws NameAlreadyExistsException
        Adds a group of radio buttons with the specified name, label orientation and x,y co-ordinate to the form. The buttons are labeled by the Strings passed as a parameter. The number of buttons will be the number of Strings passed. The radio buttons are arranged either verticaly (true) or horizontally (false) depending on the parameter vertical. If the paramter vertical is omitted the buttons are arranged vertically. Leaving out the name means the radio buttons can only be accessed via iterating through the elements on the form. Leaving out the other paramters will result in them having their default values. (see default values above) All of the parameters are optional, and possible combinations of them can be seen below.
        Parameters:
        name - the name radio button group component.
        label - the text to be displayed in the label.
        vertical - the radio buttons will be laid out in a vertical fashion, false for a horizontal layout
        x - the x co-ordinate of the top left corner of the radio button group
        y - the y co-ordinate of the top left corner of the radio button group
        buttons - the labels for the buttons in the radio button group
        Throws:
        NameAlreadyExistsException - the name has already been used for another component.

      • addRadioButtons

        public void addRadioButtons(java.lang.String name,
                            java.lang.String label,
                            boolean vertical,
                            java.lang.String... buttons)
        See Also:

      • addSlider

        public void addSlider(java.lang.String name,
                      java.lang.String label,
                      int min,
                      int max,
                      int size,
                      int x,
                      int y)
               throws NameAlreadyExistsException
        Adds a slider with the specified name, label, range, size and x,y co-ordinate to the form. Leaving out the name means the slider can only be accessed via iterating through the elements on the form. The default range of the slider is 0-100 and the default size is 120 pixels. Leaving out the other paramters will result in them having their default values. (see default values above) All of the parameters are optional, and possible combinations of them can be seen below.
        Parameters:
        name - the name of the slider component.
        label - the text to be displayed in the label.
        min - the minimum value of the slider
        max - the maximum value of the slider
        size - the physical size of the slider (in pixels)
        x - The x co-ordinate of the top left corner of the slider
        y - The y co-ordinate of teh top left corner of the slider
        Throws:
        NameAlreadyExistsException - the name has already been used for another component.

      • addSound

        public void addSound(java.lang.String name,
                     java.lang.String label,
                     Sound s,
                     int x,
                     int y)
        Adds a sound player (a button that when pressed will play the sound associated with the player) with specified name, label, sound and x,y co-ordinate to the form. Leaving out the name means the sound player can only be accessed via iterating through the elements on the form. Leaving out the sound means that there is no sound to be played until one is placed on the player (placeSound). Leaving out the other paramters will result in them having their default values. (see default values above) All of the parameters are optional, and possible combinations of them can be seen below.
        Parameters:
        name - the name of the sound player component
        label - the label for the sound player
        s - a sound file associated with the sound player
        x - the x co-ordinate of the top left corner of the sound player
        y - the y co-ordinate of the top left corner of the sound player
        Throws:
        NameAlreadyExistsException - the name has already been used for another component.

        See Also:

      • addCanvas

        public void addCanvas(java.lang.String name,
                      java.lang.String label,
                      int width,
                      int height,
                      int x,
                      int y)
               throws NameAlreadyExistsException
        Adds a canvas with specified name, label, size, and x,y co-ordinates to the form. This canvas can have pictures and turtles placed on it and is used to display the image of a turtle drawing or of a picture. Leaving out the name means the canvas can only be accessed via iterating through the elements on the form. If width and height are not specified the default size is 200x200. Leaving out the other paramters will result in them having their default values. (see default values above) All of the parameters are optional, and possible combinations of them can be seen below.
        Parameters:
        name - the name of the canvas
        label - a label to be associated with the canvas
        width - the width of the canvas
        height - the height of the canvas
        x - the x co-ordinate of the top left corner of the canvas
        y - the y co-ordinate of the top left corner of the canvas
        Throws:
        NameAlreadyExistsException - the name has already been used for another component.

      • addCanvas

      • writeByte

        public void writeByte(java.lang.String name,
                      byte b,
                      java.text.Format f,
                      int size)
        Writes a byte value to the specified component on the form. If no name is specified the byte value will be written to the next component. If a format is specified it will be used to format when writing the byte value otherwise the default format will be used. The display string will be truncated/padded to the specified size or will be the minimum size to represent the formatted value if no size is specified.
        Parameters:
        name - the name of the component
        b - the byte value to write
        f - the format for the write
        size - display size in characters

      • writeString

        public void writeString(java.lang.String name,
                        java.lang.String s,
                        java.text.Format f,
                        int size)
        Writes a String value to the specified component on the form. If no name is specified the String value will be written to the next component. If a format is specified it will be used to format when writing the String value otherwise the default format will be used. If size is specified, the string will be left justified in a field of size characters.
        Parameters:
        name - the field to write to
        s - the String value to write
        f - the format for the write
        size - the size of the field to write

      • clear

        public void clear()
        See Also:
        clear(String name)

      • clear

        Parameters:
        name - the name of the component

      • clearAll

        public void clearAll()
        Clears the values displayed in all components of the form.

      • close

        public void close()
        Closes the form and frees resources. The form should not be used thereafter.

      • addCustomComponent

        public void addCustomComponent(javax.swing.JComponent c)
        Adds any JComponent to the form.
